title: Expand InputDirectoryResolverTest coverage
description:
Expand InputDirectoryResolverTest to cover the full resolver contract before refactoring begins.

## Current State
- Only 3 scenarios in the TableTest, all using System.setProperty
- No coverage for the junitOutputDirOverride parameter
- No coverage for ResolutionSource return values
- No coverage for hasOutputs() preference logic

## Required Coverage

### Resolution priority
- Configured input dir wins over all other sources
- junitOutputDirOverride wins over fallback candidates
- Directory with YAML files (hasOutputs) wins over empty existing directory
- First existing directory wins when none have outputs

### ResolutionSource values
- CONFIGURED when explicit input dir provided
- JUNIT_PROPERTY when resolved via override parameter
- FALLBACK when resolved via convention candidates
- NONE when no directory found

### Path handling
- Relative paths resolved against baseDir
- Absolute paths used as-is
- Override parameter: relative and absolute

### Edge cases
- Null/empty override treated as absent
- Null fallback candidates uses defaults
- Null baseDir defaults to "."

### Candidates list
- Candidates includes all searched locations for diagnostic reporting
- Override path appears in candidates
- Fallback paths appear in candidates

## Why This Is a Prerequisite
The existing test uses System.setProperty to test JUnit property resolution — the mechanism c3b will remove. After removal, the "JUnit property" scenario must use junitOutputDirOverride instead. Comprehensive coverage before refactoring ensures we don't break existing behaviour.

File: tabletest-reporter-core/src/test/java/io/github/nchaugen/tabletest/reporter/InputDirectoryResolverTest.java
close_reason: Coverage expanded with 5 test methods covering resolution priority, path handling, search locations, and message formatting. Skill updated with lessons learned (include all outputs, match table structure to logic type, row coherence).

title: Read junit-platform.properties file
description:
Create a reader that extracts `junit.platform.reporting.output.dir` from the standard JUnit properties file.

## Location
The standard location is `junit-platform.properties` at the root of the test classpath. In practice this means `src/test/resources/junit-platform.properties` relative to the project base directory.

## Behaviour
- Read the file as a standard Java `Properties` file
- Extract the `junit.platform.reporting.output.dir` property if present
- If the value contains `{uniqueNumber}`, return the value but flag it as non-deterministic (the resolver should not try to resolve the placeholder — fall through to convention scanning instead)
- Return empty if the file doesn't exist or doesn't contain the property

## Design
Consider a separate class (e.g. `JunitPropertiesReader`) for testability and single responsibility. The resolver already does filesystem I/O but a dedicated reader keeps the parsing logic isolated and testable without needing temp directories.

## Edge Cases
- File doesn't exist → return empty
- File exists but property not present → return empty
- Property value is blank → return empty
- Property value contains `{uniqueNumber}` → return the raw value with a flag/signal
- Multiple `junit-platform.properties` on classpath → only read the conventional location
close_reason: Closed

title: Support tabletest.css as separate file

Desired Behavior:
Provide option to generate tabletest.css as a separate file that can be:
1. Referenced via <link> in HTML files
2. Shared across multiple HTML files (reduces duplication)
3. Cached by browsers for better performance
4. Modified by users without regenerating reports

Configuration Option:
```xml
<configuration>
    <format>asciidoc</format>
    <separateCss>true</separateCss>
</configuration>
```

This would generate:
- tabletest.css file in output directory
- AsciiDoc files configured to reference external stylesheet
- HTML files with <link rel="stylesheet" href="tabletest.css">

Benefits:
- Better browser caching
- Easier CSS customization
- Reduced file size when generating multiple reports
- More standard HTML structure

Related: Discovered during asciidoc-html-maven compatibility test implementation.
close_reason: Won't do: Separate CSS files are already supported via standard Asciidoctor configuration (copycss, linkcss attributes). No code changes needed in tabletest-reporter.

title: Explore CSS class support for other documentation systems
description:
TableTest Reporter currently generates AsciiDoc and Markdown. AsciiDoc supports roles that become CSS classes. This issue investigates CSS class support for Markdown.

## Research Findings (2026-01-22)

### Standard Markdown (CommonMark/GFM)
**No support** for CSS classes on table cells. GitHub, GitLab, and most basic renderers don't support any attribute syntax.

### Python-Markdown (MkDocs)
**Supported** via `attr_list` extension. Cell-level attributes work with this syntax:
```markdown
| content {.passed .expectation} |
```

Requirements:
- Must enable `attr_list` extension in `mkdocs.yml`
- Attributes must be at end of cell content
- Must be separated by space from content
- Works for both `<td>` and `<th>` elements

Limitation: Cannot set attributes on `<table>`, `<thead>`, `<tbody>`, or `<tr>` elements.

Reference: [Python-Markdown attr_list docs](https://python-markdown.github.io/extensions/attr_list/)

### Pandoc
**Limited support**. Can add attributes to some block elements but not inline table cells. Workarounds exist using Div wrappers but don't apply to individual cells.

Reference: [Pandoc User's Guide](https://pandoc.org/MANUAL.html)

### kramdown (Jekyll)
Has `{:.class}` syntax but cell-level support is inconsistent.

### markdown-it (JavaScript)
**Supported** via [markdown-it-attrs](https://github.com/arve0/markdown-it-attrs) plugin with similar `{.class}` syntax.

---

## Implementation Feasibility

**Feasible for Python-Markdown/MkDocs users** with template changes:

Current `macros.md.peb` ignores roles:
```pebble
{% macro renderCell(cell) %}
    {{- renderValue(cell.value) -}}
{% endmacro %}
```

Could be extended to:
```pebble
{% macro renderCell(cell) %}
    {{- renderValue(cell.value) -}}
    {%- if cell.roles is not empty %} {.{% for role in cell.roles %}{{ role }}{% if not loop.last %} {% endif %}{% endfor %}}{% endif -%}
{% endmacro %}
```

Output example:
```markdown
| Small {.scenario .passed} | 1 {.passed} | 2 {.passed} | 3 {.expectation .passed} |
```

**Caveat**: This breaks rendering on processors without attribute support (GitHub, GitLab). Options:
1. Add a config option to enable/disable role output in Markdown
2. Create a separate `markdown-attrs` format
3. Document as "MkDocs-compatible Markdown"

---

## Recommendation

**P3 - Low priority**. The target audience for TableTest Reporter primarily uses:
- AsciiDoc (fully supported)
- Plain Markdown for simple docs (roles not critical)

If users request MkDocs support specifically, implement as:
1. New format `markdown-mkdocs` or config option `markdown.attributes=true`
2. Update `macros.md.peb` to conditionally output `{.class}` syntax
3. Document MkDocs configuration requirements

**No immediate action needed** - wait for user demand.

title: Improve documentation update reminders in workflow
description:
The CLAUDE.md documentation mentions updating CHANGELOG.md and README.md for features, but this has become cluttered and easy to miss, especially for bug fixes.

## Current Issues
1. Documentation update section in CLAUDE.md focuses mainly on features
2. Not clear that bug fixes also need CHANGELOG.md updates
3. Section is buried in middle of workflow steps
4. No automated reminder when source files change

## Proposed Improvements

### 1. Restructure CLAUDE.md Documentation Section
- Rename "Documentation Updates for Features" → "Documentation Updates"
- Clarify that ALL user-facing changes need documentation:
  - New features → CHANGELOG.md (Added) + README.md
  - Bug fixes → CHANGELOG.md (Fixed)
  - Breaking changes → CHANGELOG.md (Changed) + README.md
  - Internal refactorings → No documentation needed
- Make section more prominent in workflow steps
- Add examples of what counts as "user-facing"

### 2. Add Pre-commit Hook Reminder
Add check in `git-hooks/pre-commit` that warns (doesn't block) when:
- Files in `tabletest-reporter-*/src/main/` are changed
- But `CHANGELOG.md` is NOT staged

Example implementation:
```bash
# Check if documentation should be updated
if git diff --cached --name-only | grep -q 'tabletest-reporter-.*/src/main/'; then
    if \! git diff --cached --name-only | grep -q 'CHANGELOG.md'; then
        echo ""
        echo "⚠️  Note: Source files changed but CHANGELOG.md not updated"
        echo "   Consider updating CHANGELOG.md if this affects users"
        echo "   (Bug fixes, new features, breaking changes need documentation)"
        echo ""
    fi
fi
```

### 3. Hook Behavior
- Warning only, not blocking (allow internal refactorings)
- Only trigger for `src/main/` changes (not test files)
- Remind about both CHANGELOG.md and README.md (for major features)

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] CLAUDE.md section restructured and clarified
- [ ] Pre-commit hook includes documentation reminder
- [ ] Hook triggers for src/main changes
- [ ] Hook is non-blocking (warning only)
- [ ] Examples added for what needs documentation

## Related
- Recent example: tabletest-reporter-wn4 (bug fix) - forgot to update CHANGELOG.md initially

title: Integrate properties file into resolver
description:
Integrate the `junit-platform.properties` reader into `InputDirectoryResolver.resolve()`.

## Resolution Order (after integration)
1. Explicit input directory (user-configured) → CONFIGURED
2. Plugin-provided JUnit output dir (`junitOutputDirOverride`) → JUNIT_PROPERTY
3. `junit-platform.properties` file value (new) → JUNIT_PROPERTY
4. Convention fallbacks (`target/junit-jupiter`, `build/junit-jupiter`) → FALLBACK

## Implementation Notes
- The resolver needs a way to locate the properties file. Options:
  - Derive from `baseDir` as `baseDir/src/test/resources/junit-platform.properties`
  - Accept an additional parameter for the properties file path (more flexible, more testable)
- If the properties value contains `{uniqueNumber}`, skip it and fall through to convention scanning
- The resolved path from properties should be added to the `candidates` list for diagnostic reporting
- Preserve the existing `Result` record structure (path, source, candidates)

## Testing
- Test with properties file present → resolves to JUNIT_PROPERTY
- Test with properties file containing `{uniqueNumber}` → falls through to FALLBACK
- Test with no properties file → falls through to FALLBACK
- Test resolution priority: override > properties file > fallback
close_reason: Closed

title: Refactor InputDirectoryResolver to single responsibility
description:
InputDirectoryResolver.resolve() currently mixes two responsibilities:

1. **Decision/priority logic**: determining which directory wins (configured > JUnit property > fallback)
2. **Parsing/validation**: interpreting directory specifications (null/empty/blank string handling, relative vs absolute path resolution)

This was surfaced during test design — rows for parsing edge cases (empty/blank JUnit dir) didn't fit naturally in a table structured around priority decisions, signalling mixed concerns.

## Suggested Approach
- Extract parsing/validation into a separate component (e.g. JunitDirParser that normalises raw string into Optional<Path>)
- Keep InputDirectoryResolver focused on priority resolution with already-parsed inputs
- Each responsibility gets its own focused test table

## Context
Discovered while expanding InputDirectoryResolverTest coverage (tabletest-reporter-26m). The test design feedback from writing TableTests highlighted the SRP violation.
close_reason: Completed: JunitDirParser extracted in 908021c, test coverage improved in 9532a11

title: Auto-detect junit.platform.reporting.output.dir
description:
## Context

The `InputDirectoryResolver` needs to auto-detect the JUnit property `junit.platform.reporting.output.dir` to find where JUnit wrote test output YAML files. The challenge is that the reporter runs at report-generation time (separate JVM from test execution), so the property value from the test run is not directly available.

## Current State

- `System.getProperty()` fallback in the resolver is effectively dead code at report time
- Only the Gradle plugin passes the value explicitly via `junitOutputDirOverride`
- Maven plugin and CLI always pass `null`
- Convention fallbacks (`target/junit-jupiter`, `build/junit-jupiter`) cover common defaults

## Key Findings

### JUnit 5 vs 6 directory structure
- **JUnit 5**: Writes directly into configured output dir
- **JUnit 6**: Prepends engine ID as subdirectory (e.g. `build/` → `build/junit-jupiter/`)
- The `junit-jupiter` name is the engine ID; other engines use different names

### {uniqueNumber} placeholder
- Config like `reports/junit-{uniqueNumber}` creates `reports/junit-8803697269315188212`
- With JUnit 6 engine ID: `reports/junit-8803697269315188212/junit-jupiter/`
- Parallel forks create multiple such directories simultaneously

### Configuration methods in practice
- Gradle: `systemProperty()` or `jvmArgumentProviders` in `tasks.test`
- Maven Surefire: Internal convention (`target/junit-jupiter`), or `configurationParameters`
- `junit-platform.properties`: Standard JUnit mechanism but rarely used (0/6 compat tests)

## Proposed Strategy (Three Tiers)

### Tier 1: Remove dead code
Remove `System.getProperty()` from `resolveJunitOutputDir`. The `junitOutputDirOverride` parameter already covers explicit passing.

### Tier 2: Read `junit-platform.properties`
- Read `src/test/resources/junit-platform.properties` relative to `baseDir`
- Extract `junit.platform.reporting.output.dir` if present
- If value contains `{uniqueNumber}`, don't try to resolve it — fall back to convention scanning
- Consider a separate `JunitPropertiesReader` class for testability

### Tier 3: Leave complex cases to the user
These are too complex for reliable auto-detection:
- `{uniqueNumber}` directories from parallel forks
- Non-standard engine IDs
- Custom `OutputDirectoryCreator` implementations
- IDE-specific output directories

### Resolution order after implementation
1. Explicit input directory (user-configured) → CONFIGURED
2. Plugin-provided JUnit output dir (`junitOutputDirOverride`) → JUNIT_PROPERTY
3. `junit-platform.properties` file (new) → JUNIT_PROPERTY
4. Convention fallbacks (`target/junit-jupiter`, `build/junit-jupiter`) → FALLBACK

## References
- JUnit reporting docs: https://docs.junit.org/6.0.2/advanced-topics/junit-platform-reporting.html
- JUnit config params: https://docs.junit.org/6.0.2/running-tests/configuration-parameters.html
- History doc: history/junit-output-compatibility-analysis.md
close_reason: Implementation complete. Tier 1 (remove dead code) done in 50f8428, Tier 2 (read properties file) done in 00e6a23 and 156e865, Tier 3 (complex cases left to user) by design. Documentation tracked separately by tabletest-reporter-i4e.

title: Prevent generation of empty index files for test classes without TableTests
description:
**Bug Report:**
Index files are generated for test classes that do not contain any TableTest methods, resulting in empty index pages with no entries.

**Current Behaviour:**
- If a test class has no @TableTest methods, an index file is still generated
- The index file contains headers/structure but no test entries
- Empty index files clutter the documentation
- Parent index files link to these empty indexes

**Expected Behaviour:**
- Index files should only be generated for test classes with at least one @TableTest
- Test classes without TableTests should be excluded from report generation
- Parent indexes should not link to non-existent child indexes

**Example Scenario:**
Test class structure:
```
com.example.tests/
  ├── CalculatorTests.java      (has @TableTest methods) ✓ should generate index
  └── UtilityTests.java         (no @TableTest methods)  ✗ should NOT generate index
```

Current: Both generate index files
Expected: Only CalculatorTests generates index file

**Root Cause (Suspected):**
- Report generation logic processes all test classes
- No filtering based on whether class contains TableTest methods
- May be in tabletest-reporter-junit module's report collection logic
- Or in tabletest-reporter-core's file generation logic

**Investigation Steps:**
1. Check how test classes are discovered/collected in tabletest-reporter-junit
2. Review filtering logic for determining which classes generate reports
3. Identify where index file generation is triggered
4. Check if TableTest method count is tracked per class
5. Review YAML generation - does it include empty test classes?

**Fix Requirements:**
- Filter out test classes with zero TableTest methods before generating files
- Ensure parent index files don't reference non-existent child indexes
- Add test case: class with no @TableTest should not generate output
- Verify fix works with CLI, Maven plugin, and Gradle plugin
- Consider: should YAML still record the class with empty methods array?

**User Impact:**
Medium - Creates clutter in documentation, confusing users about which tests actually exist. Not breaking functionality but reduces report quality.
close_reason: Closed

title: Add HTML generation compatibility test for AsciiDoc CSS classes
description:
Currently, TableTest Reporter generates AsciiDoc with custom roles (.passed, .failed, .expectation) that should become CSS classes in HTML output. However, we have no automated test verifying this works correctly.

**Current State:**
- Templates generate roles: [.expectation]#value#, [.passed]#value#, [.failed]#value#
- Example: [.expectation.passed]#++3++# from generated .adoc files
- AsciiDoc roles should become CSS classes when processed to HTML

**Goal:**
Add compatibility test that:
1. Generates TableTest report as AsciiDoc
2. Processes .adoc files with Asciidoctor Maven/Gradle plugins
3. Verifies resulting HTML contains correct CSS classes
4. Tests with custom CSS stylesheet to ensure classes are applicable

**Implementation:**
- Add test project to compatibility-tests/ using asciidoctor-maven-plugin
- Add test project using asciidoctor-gradle-plugin  
- Include sample CSS stylesheet
- Verify HTML output contains expected class attributes
- Could use jsoup or similar to parse and validate HTML structure

**Benefits:**
- Ensures role→class conversion works across Asciidoctor versions
- Documents by example how to set up HTML generation
- Catches regressions in template role generation
close_reason: Scenario role verification added: implicit detection (testAddition, testMultiplication) and explicit @Scenario annotation (testSubtraction) both tested with CSS class verification

title: Research indexify pattern support for AsciiDoc HTML publishing
description:
Research whether supporting the 'indexify' pattern would be beneficial for publishing TableTest reports.

## Background
AsciiDoc supports an 'indexify' pattern where all HTML files are moved into subdirectories:
- Traditional: `filename.html`
- Indexify: `filename/index.html` (accessible as `/filename`)

This is controlled via asciidoctor attributes:
```
:relfileprefix: ../
:relfilesuffix: /
```

## Current Implementation
We currently generate:
- Index files: `calculator-tests/index.html`
- Table files: `calculator-tests/addition.html`

Links are handled conditionally in templates based on node type.

## Research Questions
1. Do common documentation publishing systems (GitHub Pages, GitLab Pages, ReadTheDocs, Netlify) benefit from or require indexify pattern?
2. Would indexify pattern provide better SEO or URL aesthetics?
3. What would be required to support indexify in our templates?
4. Would this be a breaking change for existing users?
5. Should this be configurable or always-on?

## References
- AsciiDoc docs: Mapping references to different structure (relfileprefix/relfilesuffix)
- Related fix: tabletest-reporter-wn4 (index-to-index links)

## Acceptance Criteria
- Document which publishing systems benefit from indexify
- Recommend whether to support it (yes/no/optional)
- If yes, outline implementation approach and breaking changes

title: Fix AsciiDoc index-to-index links becoming document references in HTML
description:
**Bug Report:**
Users report that links from index files to other index files in subdirectories are incorrectly generated in AsciiDoc reports. When converted to HTML, these links become document references (anchors) instead of proper file links.

**Current Behaviour:**
- Link to index file in 'mapping' subfolder generates as: `href="#./mapping"`
- This creates an anchor reference within the current document
- Clicking the link does nothing or jumps to non-existent anchor

**Expected Behaviour:**
- Link should generate as: `href="mapping/index.html"` (or similar valid path)
- Clicking should navigate to the subfolder's index file
- Relative paths should work correctly in generated HTML

**Example:**
From root index.adoc linking to mapping/index.adoc:
- ❌ Current: `link:#./mapping[Mapping Tests]`
- ✅ Expected: `link:mapping/index.html[Mapping Tests]`

**Root Cause (Suspected):**
- Likely in index.adoc.peb or macros.adoc.peb templates
- Link generation logic incorrectly formats paths to index files
- May be treating folder paths as document anchors

**Investigation Steps:**
1. Review templates: index.adoc.peb, macros.adoc.peb
2. Check how links to subdirectory index files are generated
3. Test with compatibility tests to reproduce issue
4. Verify AsciiDoc link syntax for cross-document references

**Fix Requirements:**
- Generate proper relative file paths for index-to-index links
- Ensure links work correctly when AsciiDoc is converted to HTML
- Add test case to prevent regression
- Verify fix works with asciidoctor-maven-plugin and asciidoctor-gradle-plugin

**User Impact:**
High - Navigation in generated HTML documentation is broken, making multi-level test reports unusable.
close_reason: Closed

title: Add error handling unit tests (moderate scope)
description:
Add moderate error handling unit tests covering common user mistakes.

**Core module (ReportTreeErrorTest):**
- Non-existent input directory → clear error message
- Empty input directory → empty result
- Directory with no YAML files → empty result
- Malformed YAML file → skip with warning or fail with message

**Template rendering errors:**
- Missing template for format → error listing available formats
- Template syntax error → error with location

**CLI module (extend TableTestReporterCliTest):**
- Missing required arguments → usage message
- Non-existent input directory → clear error
- Non-existent template directory → clear error
- Unknown format → list available formats

**Scope: Moderate** - Focus on common user mistakes, not every edge case.
close_reason: Implemented error message UX improvements: YAML errors show file path, empty directories show informational message, success shows file count
